title: feat: make it possible to create and load scalar indices for a dataset
body:
Three new methods are added to the dataset (via `DatasetIndexExt`):

 * `open_generic_index`
 * `open_scalar_index`
 * `open_vector_index`

Previously, there had only been `open_index` which was a free function (that took a `&Dataset`) and returned a `Arc<dyn VectorIndex>`.  That method still exists as an internal helper but users should now use `Dataset::open_vector_index` instead.

In addition, there is a new `IndexType` for `Scalar` and the `create_index` method will recognize this type.  Creating a scalar index currently does not require any parameters but it may in the future.

Opening a vector index today is rather involved.  First the proto metadata is loaded from disk.  This describes the detailed vector-specific parameters of the index (the index information in the manifest is very high-level and common across vector and scalar index types).  The scalar index does not need that today because we can assume all scalar indices are btree backed by flat.  As a result, we did not need to make any changes to any .proto files.  In the future, should we add new types of scalar indices and new parameters, we should be able to handle that similarly.  These could either be added to the existing `index.proto` or maintained in their own `scalar_index.proto` (or even stored in some other format entirely).

The generic `Index` trait has moved into `lance-index` and is required by both `ScalarIndex` and `VectorIndex`.  This trait has all of the "common" index operations.  Right now this is only a single method to fetch the statistics but in the future it will hopefully include things like remap and update/optimize.

The index statistics were previously returned as a `serde_json::Value`.  This is now returned as a simple `String`.

5. Reduce the size of the KMeans test to something that runs in a reasonable amount of time. On my machine it takes over a minute too finish, which is too slow for iteration.
6. Fix tracing so it filters out other packages messages.

title: Coalesce IO requests in an IO scheduler
body:
Right now, we coalesce requests if they are within some size, but this only happens if we have context for them. Sometimes we might have two contiguous requests that could be combined, but they don't have context to know about each other. For example, if three i32 columns are being read in parallel (each request is 1024 * 4 = 4096), their buffers might be right next to each other, in which case the read could be just one 12Kb read.

This kind of scheduling is important to be competitive against row-based formats for random reads, since right now our row-level reads are `O(num columns retrieved)`. To make this more useful, we might consider rearranging buffers so small column types are placed together.

We might take some inspiration from the design of Linux IO schedulers (such as Kyber). See: https://lwn.net/Articles/720675/ (The existence of these likely means that we just have to implement this for object storage, not local filesystems. Although it might be interesting to come up with recommendations on the best Linux IO scheduler settings for Lance.)

In addition, object stores [often recommend cancelling and retrying a request if it is taking unusually long](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/optimizing-performance-guidelines.html#optimizing-performance-guidelines-retry). This can help reduce p99 latencies. There is some research into this as well: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0167819118302138. We should see if it's worth integrating this into the scheduler, if it's not already handled by object store.

title: Expose order_by / sorting to python
body:
#1498 is adding sorting options to the scanner.  We should expose those to python.  Sorting is the first operator (I think) that could potentially accumulate.  When we expose this to python we should address two things:

 * The sort operator can also take a "fetch limit" to convert the sort into a RAM efficient "top k".  If the query is not an ANN/KNN search but the query DOES have a limit then we should use the limit as the top k.
 * If the query has no ANN/KNN search and no limit then we need to worry about running out of memory.  We should a bounded [GreedyMemoryPool](https://docs.rs/datafusion/latest/datafusion/execution/memory_pool/struct.GreedyMemoryPool.html) when configuring the datafusion runtime.  In fact, we can probably always use a bounded pool if that is easier (i.e. there is no harm in using a bounded pool in queries that don't have sorts)

title: perf: dimension-based kernel for L2 and Cosine
body:
Provide faster routine for large PQ training, where each subvector only has 8 floats.

L2:

```
L2(simd,f32x8)          time:   [1.9428 ms 1.9509 ms 1.9561 ms]
                        change: [-26.987% -25.863% -24.769%] (p = 0.00 < 0.10)
                        Performance has improved.
```

Cosine:

```
Cosine(simd,8-f32) rng seed
                        time:   [2.8588 ms 2.8693 ms 2.8960 ms]
                        change: [-62.852% -62.407% -61.952%] (p = 0.00 < 0.10)
                        Performance has improved.
```

body: This uses datafusion to sort the scanner results.  It will be needed for training scalar indices.  In addition, this PR adds some new capabilities to the array generators that I was using for testing the sort method.

title: ci: cancel in progress runs on new push
body: Adds concurrency config to cancel in progress actions when new commit pushed to PR or branch: https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#concurrency When we have a PR open, and we notice some CI job has failed, it's common to immediately push a new commit with the fix before all the jobs have finished. This will start a new batch of jobs for the PR, but the old ones will continue to run in the background and will possibly also fail. This leads to confusing behaviour where we'll later receive emails about failed jobs on a PR from old commits.

Proposal: enforce patch version bumps don't have breaking changes
body:
Right now, we don't promise API stability while we are on 0.X releases. This means that downstream packages (such as LanceDB) have to pin to an exact version, or else risk breaking changes. Because of this pinning, each time we release a new version, we have to also make a PR incrementing the pinned pylance version in LanceDB.

Proposal: we could require that if there is a breaking change, there should be a **minor** version bump and not a **patch** version bump. To help identify breaking changes, we should make sure we have a tag in PR titles per [conventional commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/). (For example, `feat(api!): change API for XXX`.) Then downstream packages could pin to `~=0.X.0` and automatically receive compatible updates.

This enforcement is compatible with [semantic versioning](https://semver.org/).

title: chore: remove outdated warnings about prefiltering with a vector index
Use datafusion kernel to do IVF partition shuffling
body:
Most of the time, `num_partitions` >> `num_rows_per_partition`. For example, you might have 10,000 partitions each with 256 rows. Thus it's not practical to buffer the partition data in memory.

Instead, we can do the partitioning by performing a disk-spilling sort. This kind of sort is already supported by DataFusion, so we can implement it with the query plan:

1. Projection: assign partition id, replace vector column with PQ codes. (see: [transform.rs](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/main/rust/lance-index/src/vector/pq/transform.rs), [residual.rs](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/main/rust/lance-index/src/vector/residual.rs))
2. Sort: sort by partition id, making sure to set a memory limit so we spill to disk
3. Group By: group by partition id (we'll likely do the group by ourselves, since I don't think DF can optimize grouping sorted data)
4. For each group, write partition to index.

title: bug: handle rewriting Arrow List `value_field` from DuckDB
body:
DuckDB seems to write the `value_field` of list as `"l"` rather than what Arrow expects (`"item"`) or Parquet uses (`"element"`). Why, I cannot guess. However, Lance doesn't seem to handle this:

```python
import lance
import pyarrow
import duckdb


my_table = pyarrow.Table.from_pydict({
    'id': [1, 1, 2, 2],
    'data': [1, 2, 3, 4],
})

grouped = duckdb.query('''
    select
        id,
        list(data)
    from my_table
    group by id
''').to_arrow_table()

lance_ds = lance.write_dataset(grouped, 'test_lance')
lance_ds.to_table()
```

results in

```
ArrowInvalid: C Data interface error: Io error: Execution error: External error: Execution error: LanceError(Arrow): Invalid argument error: column types must match schema types, expected List(Field { name: "l", data_type: Int64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }) but found List(Field { name: "item", data_type: Int64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }) at column index 1
```

title: perf: various improvements for faster L2 kmeans
feat: add btree scalar index
body:
This PR fleshes out the concept of a scalar index.  It creates a btree-inspired index as an initial example index.  The index is modeled very similarly to the vector index and will also closely resemble an IVF index.

The index is broken into two parts, the lookup table / btree and the data pages (leaf nodes).  The lookup table is stored on disk as a lance table with a single record batch containing the min/max/null count/offset of each data page (the offset is currently superfluous and I'll probably remove it as I clean this up).  The data pages are stored on disk as a lance table with one record batch per page.  When we load the lookup table into memory we convert it into a btree.

An index search first uses the btree to figure out which pages might satisfy the query.  We then load those pages into memory and search through them with a flat scan.  In the future we could investigate storing leaf pages in some b-tree like structure but since they are likely to be small enough to fit into a single IOPS I'm not sure there would be much benefit.

To train, the btree index needs a stream of batches.  These batches should be rechunked into smallish chunks.  Each batch should contain two columns, the value and the row id.  The batches should be sorted by the value column.  There is very little compute and the entire operation will probably be I/O bound and fairly quick (however long it takes to sort and scan the data) but memory intensive (no out-of-core sort yet).

The one parameter we have is the size of these data pages.  For example, we could decide each page is 4096 rows.  This would mean, with 1Bi rows, we would have 256Ki pages.  Our lookup table should still be fairly small (e.g. if the values are 4 byte integers then the lookup table will be ~3MiB.)

title: Refactor: extract expensive constructions to allow reusing
body:
When opening a dataset, we have quite a few expensive and reusable constructions.
* AWS credential construction (can be 200ms+)
* S3 store construction (20-50ms)
* DynamoDB cold connection (20-50ms)

All of these instance can be injected and reused instead of recreated every time

title: add_columns dataset API
body:
We have an `add_columns()` API for fragments, and a `merge()` API for dataset. It would be nice to create a `add_columns()` API for dataset that is similar to the one for fragments.

It would also be very nice to add progress tracking as an option there, since this might be a long operation. For example, users might call this API to add a new embedding column to the dataset.

title: Support "packing" columns to allow faster retrieval of groups of many columns
body:
Fetching many columns from disk can result in a lot of I/O requests.  These can sometimes be coalesced into fewer requests at the cost of increasing the amount of data we need to read.

However, there is another approach we can take.  If we know a group of columns is always (or frequently) going to be fetched together then we can pack them together when we store them.  In other words, we would store these columns as a "packed row".

Before

A: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
B: [6, 7, 8, 9, 10]
C: [11, 12, 13, 14, 15]

After B & C are "packed"

A: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
BC: [6-11, 7-12, 8-13, 9-14, 10-15]

This means fetching a single column from a packed set is more expensive (e.g. fetching just C) but fetching all columns in the packed set should be considerably quicker.

title: Upsert (merge) operation to atomically modify / add / remove rows in a single operation
body:
In other databases this is called Merge:

- [Snowflake](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/merge)
- [Databricks / Delta Lake](https://docs.databricks.com/en/sql/language-manual/delta-merge-into.html)
- [Redshift](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/latest/dg/r_MERGE.html)

Users want this to be able to insert rows while making sure there aren’t duplicate rows inserted. Right now they have to do this in two transactions: (1) delete the old rows and then (2) add the new rows. This means they need to know which ones are in the table. It also means there is a moment where clients get back fewer rows that they should.

More generally, `MERGE` queries allow taking a data source of `create`, `update`, and `delete` events and apply them to a table in a single transaction.

title: Feature Request: simple secondary indexes
body:
For traditional ML use cases which do not use embeddings secondary indexes which operate on other types would be very useful in an inference/deployment scenario. Useful indexes may include:

- BitMap index
- BTree index
- Adaptive Radix Tree (ART) 
- Hash index

For many use cases the BitMap index might be particularly suitable with the additional benefit of its relative simplicity of implementation.

title: fix: fix an issue where the GPU index trainer was taking too much data into memory
body:
the old computation calculated `k * sample_rate` as `sample_size` and then took the whole dataset unless there were `k * sample_size` rows which is `k * k * sample_rate`.  I've reworded the logic to hopefully be a bit clearer.

Once this was fixed the next issue was that the `dataset.sample` method doesn't actually exist and so I added it.

title: feat: add parameter to split by file size
body:
It's possible to hit the max size for object-store (100GB). (This limit is set by the multi-part upload implementation, not the underlying stores themselves.)

To help users avoid this, we provide a new `max_bytes_per_file` settings in `WriteParams`. This is checked as we flush each batch.

For users of the `Fragment.create()` API, we provide an alternative called `write_fragments()` that can split into multiple fragments if relevant limits are hit.

title: feat: make tell synchronous and infallible
body: `Writer::tell()` is a little awkward right now as it's async and fallible, even though there's not a good reason for either of those. If we keep track of the cursor in the writer, we can simplify the method.

When we cross FFI boundary from python into rust, SIGINT does not stop the program.

title: feat: allow prefiltering to be used with an index

title: refactor: refactor Lance FileWriter to lacne-core
test: fix flaky tests involving tokio::fs::File
body: When a tokio::fs::File is dropped it does not wait for any ongoing writes to finish (as this would be a synchronous blocking wait).  Instead, it is recommended that you call `shutdown` or `flush`.  This was causing some unit tests to fail intermittently because we were creating a `File`, writing to it, then immediately reading from it.  Sometimes these reads would fail because the data had not actually been written yet.

title: refactor: migrate schema and data types to lance-core
perf: better parallelism in delete vector prefiltering
body:
The previous handling of delete files in an ANN search was sub optimal in a few ways that are fixed by this PR:

 * The synchronous portion of applying the prefilter was not run in parallel across the different PQ pages.  Now it is run in parallel as part of the spawn_cpu critical section.
 * The synchronous work of calculating the prefilter (converting from delete file to, previously, a hashmap) was repeated for each PQ page.  Now we run this once, in parallel with the IVF centroid calculation and any IVF/PQ page loading.
 * The prefilter was using a computationally heavy HashSet.  Now we use a roaring treemap.

title: fix: re-enable logging source error for dynamodb errors

perf: use selection vector strategy to improve exact knn performance with deletions
body:
This PR repurposes the `_rowid` column's validity buffer as a selection vector. By using a selection vector, we can defer the mem copies involved with applying deletions to columnar data, which is a big bottleneck in KNN queries with deletions.

For convenience, we make the `_distance` column nullable. The final output will never be null, but we sometimes will have the intermediate values be null.

Closes #1352

TODO: 
* [x] switch to using `_rowid` validity bitmap as selection vector.

title: feat: implement native compact-on-write on append path
